content.text: My name is *Zeno De Ridder* and I am a 31-years-old, Brussels-based artist who's passionate about art and storytelling. I've always been interested n experimenting with different ways to tell stories and I love to design unconventional visual styles to support those stories. Ten years ago I got my degree in audiovisual arts and since then I've dabbled my toes in many different art disciplines ranging from animation, illustration, film and theater to documentary, music and most recently game development. (Under the name Pixel Potemkin)

I never felt the need to stop and specialize, or rather; I often feel the urge to explore working with different or combined media in new styles and techniques. So when I reflected on which of my works I'd wanted to showcase here, it wasn't easy to choose.

I eventually settled on more or less standalone art pieces that would look nice on the playdate's one-bit screen. These works mostly fall into the category of 'in-between doodling and aimless prototyping' but I still am fond of them and happy to be able to share them here.

content.text: *Fortibus* - I picked up the habit of drawing and doodling from a young age and continued doing so throughout most of my life. For some time though, I didn't doodle as much anymore because I spent most of my time making drawings and animations for specific projects.

This one, I made a few years back in a period where I wanted to get back into the habit of free-flow doodling. Most of the doodles from this period were more hectic and abstract as I didn't try to structure them in any way. Fortibus was a bit different as I wanted to explore ways to mix this doodle style with more figurative structures and geometry.
I might have been watching Samurai Jack around the time I drew this. I'm getting some Aku vibes!

content.text: *Matryoshka* - This sketch is inspired by the famous Russian wooden doll and is another attempt of mixing the figurative with the abstract. Somehow linking this style to the concept of this nested puppet resonated well with me.

content.text: *Alien Font* - I made this 'alien font' for the first game prototype I ever made. 'The Museum of Forgotten Bones' was the name of the project. The idea was to offer a tour through an alien museum that revolved around the extinction of all life on the rather insignificant planet earth. In the story, the  museum is closing because it doesn't draw enough visitors, and planet Earth will be forgotten soon after. All text displayed in the menus and museum would be displayed in this font and translated by the game narrator. All in all, it was a cynical and often bleak project, but it had a nice atmosphere going for it. The decorative nature of this font was inspired partly by eastern scripts but mostly came from leaning into my free-flow doodling style.

content.text: *Shady Business* - This image is from another game prototype. The working title at the time was: 'Steven's Sunglasses Shop' but I came up with 'Shady Business' later and think it's an even more fitting name for this silly game idea. The player is Steven, an anticapitalist shop owner, offering anyone a free pair of sunglasses who manages to make his day. But to pay the rent (and to keep your wife from divorcing you) players need to sometimes sell pairs as well, much to Steven's dissatisfaction. The gameplay revolves around balancing Steven's motivation against his sense of reality. Customers enter the shop and do some dances, sing some songs or tell jokes and riddles. The player decides as Steven which customers get free glasses and which ones need to pay.
Although this project is put aside I still often think about it and I hope in the future I can pick it up again.

content.text: *Crankbot* - This little robot is the first thing I made for the playdate. It's a tiny experiment to explore possible uses for the beloved crank. The mechanical nature of a robot lends itself perfectly to map different robot functions to the crank depending on which d-pad button is held down. Left and right could spin the wheels of the robot to move the robot in opposite directions, and using the up button with the crank extends/shortens the neck segments. I'm not an experienced programmer or level designer at all, so before I chew off more than I could handle, I decided to stop working on this idea to explore Pulp as tool to bring a story or experience to playdate.

content.text: *The Temple at Mothering Rock* - A still from another Pulp experiment. Animated in Aseprite and imported into Pulp with an Aseprite script (shared kindly by user Kleist on the playdate dev forum)

I made this temple scene shortly after a vacation to Sri Lanka and its many temples. Sri Lanka's culture and history left me clearly inspired. At this time however, I had already committed to working on my first Pulp game, about a fictional art gallery. The style for that project stems largely from my free-flow doodle approach where I try to mix abstract with figurative elements. So being in this free-flowing drawing mode quickly brought my mind back to Sri Lanka. While this scene is not included in my gallery game, it might form the basis for a future project.
Those interested in seeing more about my art gallery project for playdate can check out the following link:
